Here are three of my favorite websites from my ELA Choice Board for early finishers. 👏🏻 

❤️ @scholasticinc Story Starters:
Students can pick a theme and then a story starter. You can have students write a story in Google Docs or on a piece of paper. It’s a great way to spark creativity in writing or to practice skills for narrative writing (dialogue, sequence of events, etc.). 

❤️ @natgeo for Kids:
This site has so many interesting videos and games students can explore. You can have them write down unanswered questions or wonderings, or even summaries of what they learned. Set it up in a Google Doc!

❤️Art for Kids Hub:
This site has so many directed drawings for students to choose from. They can pick one to match their story from Story Starters or they can draw a new one! It’s a great opportunity for students to practice step by step directions while also having creativity. 

Use the link in my bio to submit your email and have the link for the board sent straight to your inbox! 👏🏻 And if you’re already subscribed-check your email. 

Side note: This song was the first CD I ever bought when I was in the fifth grade! 🤪

Word problems. Story problems. Multi-step problems. 😆 

No matter what you call them, we have to make sure students have the scaffolds to deconstruct the problem, evaluate the problem, and explain their thinking when solving the problem. 

I created and used this math graphic organizer to do just that! 👏🏻 

I found great success in utilizing this organizer while teaching and my students felt more prepared to analyze word problems when using this graphic. 

You can find this resource in my shop. Link in my bio.

Another great lesson during your first week back to school after winter break is this agamograph activity. 👏🏻 This activity is centered around reading Martin’s Big Words and having your students pick one of their own words for the new year. 🤗 

Start by reading Martin’s Big Words and hold a discussion about what BIG words mean. Collect all of their ideas on an anchor chart and ask your students to think of their own BIG word. 👍🏻 

Here’s where the agamograph comes in! Students can choose one BIG word and create their own design using the word. Then they can color and decorate the template that has “2023” on it. Put them together to create an agamograph. 😍 

For this display in 2020, I hot-glued their agamograph on my @rettelco roller. I even used the pretty shelf to display my favorite MLK books. 🥰

You can also hot-glue them onto a square piece of black construction paper for easy display. 

 It was such a fun project! 

My students wanted to make more to take home. Find the template in my shop! It’s linked in my bio. 🎉

Oh wait. There aren’t any. 👊🏻 

Direct instruction needs to be used in ALL CONTENT AREAS!

It gives students clear models of what to do, provides scaffolding and checking for understanding, and is one the MOST EFFECTIVE means of teaching complex content. 

It has a .59 effect size, according to John Hattie’s meta-analysis, which means more than one year’s growth in one year’s time. 

Want to see your students’ achievement increase? Teach using direct instruction.

When I teach a novel, I also incorporate picture books that have a similar theme. With my favorite novel, The Miraculous Journey of Edward Tulane, I use the stories Bun Bun Button and The Teddy Bear because they all have a similar theme and/or story details. 📚 

This is an example of how I taught this particular unit with my third graders. 👏🏻. We were working on the compare/contrast language function and using those signal words within our writing. I modeled compare/contrast writing by comparing and contrasting the novel with one of the picture books. After I taught the lessons and modeled the writing for my students, I had my students compare/contrast the other picture book with the novel. ❤️

I used a target response, language frames to give students scaffolds when independently writing, and a four square graphic organizer. 👩🏻‍🏫

My students’ writing hit the target and then they were better prepared to continue writing using this purpose and language function. 🎯 
 
For more information on target responses, check out my blog! Link in bio.

Clearly model skills for students. 

If you’re teaching a math skill, model the skill first, list out the steps you followed, and model the skill again.

As you model, use metacognition to show what and how you’re thinking.

Write it all on an anchor chart so students can refer to it later. 

If you’re curious and to know more about Success Criteria, DM me and I’ll send you the link to The Very Busy Teacher Club Success Criteria online workshop! 👏🏻

Here’s a quick classroom management tip! 👏🏻 

Instead of saying, “Wait until I finish saying the directions before you start,” use a code word or special phrase. 

Tell students that they need to listen for that word or phrase and that is their cue to start the activity or get out their supplies. It can be as simple as “Wait until I say ‘go’” or something like “Unicorn.” 🦄 When they hear that phrase it means they can start whatever it is you needed them to start. It keeps them engaged in what you’re saying and they’ll actually know when you’re done explaining the directions. 

Which code word or special phrase are you going use? Tell me 👇🏻.

If you’re a subscriber, then you’ve been receiving my monthly kindness calendars. Every month, a new calendar is sent straight to your inbox in hopes that you challenge your students to participate in an act of kindness each day.❤️

In addition to sharing the daily act of kindness, here are four other ideas on how you can share this calendar with your students. 👏🏻

💫 Caught Being Kind Tickets: Recognize students showing kindness by creating a kindness raffle box. When students see someone being kind, they can use these little notecards to write what they saw. Students place them into the kindness raffle box (that you can make out of anything) and then you can hold a raffle at the end of the day. Check out my blog to grab these tickets for free. I also linked my Amazon list with my favorite raffle prizes.

💫Kindness Challenge Board: This bulletin board set all of the daily kindness challenges written out that correspond with the monthly kindness calendar. All you have to do is change it on the bulletin board. You can also have students use post-it notes to write down times when they’ve seen people completing that particular act of kindness. It would be a great way to get students engaged and make the board interactive. You can even share the post-it notes with students at the end of the during a closing meeting with your class. You can find this bulletin board set in my shop.

💫Kindness Poster Set: Use the kindness calendar in conjunction with these kindness quote posters! Display these posters all year long or display them as they correspond with each monthly calendar. They can even be a part of your daily kindness challenge bulletin board display. Find them in my shop.

💫Communicate with Parents: Make the monthly kindness calendars a part of communication with your students’ families. Send it home with your regular newsletters or as a separate monthly email. Encourage families to practice the acts of kindness at home, on weekends, and to share with others. Ask parents and families to engage in conversations about how their children showed kindness while in school and how it’s connected to the monthly calendar.

Read more on my blog! 😍 Link in bio.

Success Criteria Tip #5: 
Set students up for success in writing by letting them see and understand the rubric before and during writing. 👏🏻 

Writing assessments should not be a surprise for students. They should know what to expect and should also be a part of the assessment process. Do that by giving students writing exemplars (or target responses) and using those to co-construct rubrics as a class or cooperative group. 

By making them a part of the process and letting them know about what’s expected, you’ll get your students so much more engaged in writing! 

Want to learn more about success criteria? Use the link in my bio to check out my online Success Criteria Workshop. ❤️

Give students a fiction or nonfiction passage to read. 

Before they read it, tell them a prompt they will be answering after the read the passage. Create a question that is aligned with a language function (compare/contrast, opinion, cause/effect, etc.). You can have them write it on post-it note, or you can write it on the board. If you use my Discussion Cards, you can type it write into the editable file.

Read the passage as a whole group, repeat the question, and have students go back and read the passage again on their own - this time annotating details that will help them respond to the question.

Then tell students to use the language frames to answer the question. Make sure that your language frames align with the language function you used in the question. My Discussion Cards have templates for the different language functions. 

After students have time to write down their answers, have them share their answers with their A/B partners. 

Then ask for volunteers who’d like to share with the class!

Repeat these steps while reading the same passage. You’ll start to see how many students want to volunteer and how much their writing and speaking improves. 

Find the Discussion Cards using the link in my bio!

These fun, foldable printables can be used to reinforce information your students have learned or will learn about some famous women in honor of Women’s History Month. 

They’re simple and easy to distribute and use. Just print/copy front to back, fold, and assign!

They can be used for small groups, early finishers, or in addition to a craft you’re completing. 

These foldables have a brief summary about six different, important women, vocabulary definitions, and fun facts. You’ll learn about:
⭐️ Margaret Thatcher
⭐️ Queen Elizabeth I
⭐️ Amelia Earhart
⭐️ Joan of Arc
⭐️ Marie Curie
⭐️ Mother Teresa

On the reverse side of the foldable students can color a picture of the icon, answer comprehension questions about the biography, and write facts about each person using the vocabulary word.

Use the link in my bio to find this resource in my shop.

Love this question! 

When I was in the classroom, I wrote the learning goals on anchor chart paper at the start of each lesson. 

Using anchor chart paper helped me and my students. 

It made it easy for me to write and save learning goals/success criteria for each lesson, and it was a portable piece of paper I could move around the classroom as needed. 

Using anchor charts for learning goals was great for students because it created a way to showcase everything they had learned throughout a unit.

Here’s a fun and thoughtful end of the year gift you can give to your students.🙌🏻

Type up a letter with the title “I Will Remember” or “I Will Miss,” and write out what you’ll miss or remember about your students. 🥰 Include their names and make it personal. Print them out as a letter or in a 4x6 size to place into a plastic magnetic frame.

You can also print out a quote that resonates with your class, like the “Be the Nice Kid” quote. Put that into a small photo key chain and make that a part of the gift too.

Last year I decided to add a friendship bracelet to the gift and I packaged them all together in a cellophane bag. ❤️

You can find all the templates and links to this gift using the link in my bio! 😍

🌟 Quick Tip 🌟 

Let students use their desks or the small group table as a whiteboard. It's a small incentive that will keep your students engaged, help them show their work, and help you check for understanding.

Two elements of an effective direct instruction lesson are clear steps and a clean model showing how to complete the steps. It’s essential to do these two things before students go into guided and independent practice.

The last week of school is always 🤪 .

I usually try to make it engaging and fun with a week of themed days where we review all that we’ve learned, but also have a blast.

Here are some of my favorite themes:

🍉Watermelon Day
Dress in watermelon colors or watermelon shirts. Have a fruit tasting hour and survey the others on their favorite fruits. Create some watermelon art. Finally, make a watermelon EXPLODE! Find all the printables for this day in my shop that’s linked in my bio.

📖 Book Character Day
Dress up like your favorite book characters. Write stories and have an Author’s Tea with treats and lemonade. Invite parents to be mystery readers and have students read their own stories in an “author’s chair.”

⚾️ Sports Day
Wear your favorite sports jersey. Play all the sports! Survey students across grade levels about their favorite sports and what games and activities they want to see added on the school playground. Find all the printables for this day in my shop that’s linked in my bio.

☮️ Decades Day
Dress up from another decade. Have students research facts from different decades and create posters to show what they’ve learned.

I have more details on my @orientaltrading Fun365 blog post that’s linked in my bio. 👏🏻 Don’t forget to check out the end of the year resources in my shop, too! 😍

Happy Teacher Appreciation Week! 🍎

Today I’m reminiscing (and going through old photos) about past teacher appreciation days since 2009. 👏🏻

I felt the love through gifts and flowers, but also through kind words, notes, and student drawings.

But remember, you don’t need gifts to know you’re a good teacher. ❤️

I didn’t always receive these types of presents every year, but I knew that I was still a good teacher who was (and is still) making an impact. I think what makes me really acknowledge my impact as a teacher is when parents and students reach out years later to simply say “thank you.”

As John Hattie says, “Know thy impact.” You make one everyday.

With all that said, I want to thank all of YOU for your positive impact on kids. 😍

Swipe all the way through to the end of these pictures for an afternoon @starbucks treat on me!

Let’s talk intervention! 💫 

Our time with our students is valuable and we need to be intentional when we think about our schedule, lesson plans, and intervention goals.

Once districts and schools shift their focus to intentionality and purpose, progress is made.

One area of focus that can produce higher student achievement and increase student participation in learning is through planning targeted intervention blocks with intention.

This always works best when you work with your grade level team, share collective efficacy, and if you believe ALL students can learn and improve. 

This will also be effective if you dedicate a specific time of the day, every day, to target interventions.

If you don’t already have something in place, start with one content area.

When we started our intervention journey in my California school (where I taught third and fifth grade for 10 years), we chose to begin with math and called our intervention time “Power Time.” 

Immediately after recess, we dedicated 30 minutes to math intervention. 

We were intentional and explicit in what we wanted our students to do while we worked with our small groups, and we were specific with our learning targets, data tracking, and future planning.

Want to read more about the structure? 

Comment “intervention” below and I’ll DM you the link to my blog post with more information. 🥳

#teachersofig #teachingideas #academicintervention #classroomtips #teachertips #teacherlife

I got this GREAT idea from a 6th-grade teacher friend of mine a few years back and I am in love! 😍⁠
⁠
It’s a Classroom Book Club.⁠
⁠
Here’s how it works.

I chose a weekday that worked best for my class and I had my students join me for lunch on that day. 📚 During eating time at lunch, my students who wanted to be in the book club came and ate lunch with me. We talked about the book we were reading for our book club. They had to read assigned pages at home to be prepared for our weekly meeting. I purchased the books for our book club from the $1 book of the month through @scholasticbookclubs. I usually had enough bonus points to get each student in the book club a copy. 👌🏻⁠
⁠
The first year I did this, I had 19 out of 25 students sign up to be a part of our lunchtime book club. ❤️ ⁠ Then as years went by, I had my full class join me and students from different classes asked to join too. 
⁠
It’s great to try for as you continue to build relationships in this first part of the school year. 

Which books would you choose for your book club?!⁠
⁠

Each day this week, provide students with lined paper and write one of these prompts on the board for students to answer.

Stand at your classroom door and greet every student with a smile and handshake, fist bump, elbow bump, or high five.

After giving students a few minutes to complete the prompt, have them reread it and keep it in their minds for the day.

Here are the prompts for each day this week: 
(don’t forget to save it!)

1. Write down a positive affirmation or phrase that you can carry with you throughout the day. For example, “I am capable of learning and growing.”

2. What’s one thing you’re looking forward to at school today? It could be a subject you enjoy, a fun activity, or seeing a friend. 

3. Think of one small act of kindness you can do for someone today, whether it’s a classmate, a teacher, or a family member. Write down your plan.

4. List three things you’re grateful for in your life right now. These could be people, experiences, or things that make you happy.

5. Set a specific goal for today. What’s something you want to achieve or accomplish? It could be related to academics, behavior, or personal growth.

These prompts are designed to help students cultivate a positive mindset, focus on the good aspects of their day, and set achievable goals. It can create a sense of purpose and motivation as they begin their school day.

These are my top three tips for parent/teacher conferences.👏🏻

1️⃣Always start with something positive!
This is by far the most important thing you can do. Even if you have to dig deep, find something positive. It could be about their smile, their laugh, the way they always make connections to their experiences. Try not to start off right away with data and evidence. Take a breath and start by saying “First off, I just have to tell you (insert a positive story/trait).” It will lighten the mood and calm everyone’s nerves.

2️⃣Talk about academics AND citizenship/behavior.
Academics are just as important as citizenship and behavior. Make sure to touch upon the student’s strengths in BOTH areas, while also addressing areas of concern in BOTH areas. When addressing those concerns, ask the parents/guardians to support you in your plan to help the students make progress.

3️⃣Ask if the parent/guardian has any questions.
End your conference by asking the parent or guardian if they have any additional questions that you can help answer for them. And if you don’t know the answer, it’s okay to say “I’m not sure! Let me get back to you.”

What advice would you add?👇🏻

This strategy encourages students to come up with questions for the teacher and also explain why they want to know more or why they are asking that specific question.
Here’s how to implement it: 👇🏻
1. Make sure students know the learning goal and success criteria and how this task is related to the learning goal.
2. Print out the template and have it ready to use for particular lessons.
3. Give each student the handout and have them write down their questions at the end of the lesson. Make sure students explain why they are asking the question.
4. You also can use this as a reflective tool at the end of the school day.
The questions students ask can be used to brainstorm futurelesson planning. You can also use students’ questions to check in with students about their learning, to plan class meetings, or to clear up misconceptions.

This is a great school wide or grade level wide project to complete for Veterans Day! 🇺🇸 

Here’s how we did it:

Our fifth and sixth grade students created this giant American flag to show their appreciation of our nation’s veterans. 🇺🇸 We read some informative text about the origin of Veterans Day, and then discussed the importance of honoring veterans this weekend and always. ❤️ They each wrote a special statement on a red or white square to explain why it’s important to honor veterans. 👏🏻 

We also asked our school families to submit names of veterans they’d like to honor. We typed up their name, military title, relationship to the student, and displayed them on stars around the flag. 🤗 

We hope our veterans know how thankful we are for them...on Veterans Day and everyday! ❤️

From my experience, using the Jigsaw method can increase student motivation and agency, and increase students’ overall enjoyment of learning new content. It works best when it’s been modeled and if students have already learned about the content previously. 

Here’s how to implement it:
1. Make sure students know the learning goal and success criteria and how this task is related to the learning goal.
2. Break up students into smaller groups of four to six students per group, depending on the content size.
3. Assign one student to serve as the group leader or allow groups to self-select.
4. Make sure the assignment is divided up into segmented sections that equal the number of students per group.
5. Allow the group to break up the sections among themselves.
6. Set a timer and allow students to learn their part of the topic to become the “expert.”
7. When the time has expired, allow students to join with the others in the class that reviewed the same topic to share ideas and make sure they did not miss any key points.
8. Have students join back with their original groups and share out the main points and key details from their section.

As students are working, walk around and listen to their conversations. Take notes, ask questions, provide feedback, and use this time to determine your next instructional steps.

We believe dialogic teaching is true formative teaching.🤩

By embedding dialogic teaching into your instructional strategies, day in and day out, not only will you have an immediate handle on the pulse and learning in your classroom, but you will find your students are able to go far deeper into their learning and understanding than they would have via traditional in-the-moment formative assessments.

From quiet classrooms to a whole new vibe! 😎 Say hello to #DialogicTeaching!

This concept coined by Robin Alexander in the early 2000s, goes beyond the usual Q&A and transforms classrooms into dynamic spaces where teachers act as facilitators, nurturing deeper learning, thoughtful justification, and collaborative idea-building.

In a nutshell, dialogic teaching is about fostering strong relationships rather than getting caught up in specific techniques. It breaks free from the traditional hierarchical structures and ensures students get plenty of time for thinking and talking. Say goodbye to those recall-based exams – in a dialogic classroom, we’re all about sparking imagination, encouraging narration, and supporting students as they explain and justify their thoughts.

Here are 10 classroom management tips to consider for the days leading up to winter break!

🎁 Engage in Festive Activities
Incorporate holiday and winter-themed lessons and activities that are both educational and exciting. 

🎁Set Clear Holiday Expectations
Clearly communicate expectations for behavior during holiday-related activities. Emphasize the importance of maintaining a positive and respectful atmosphere, even during excitement.

🎁Plan Interactive and Hands-On Lessons
Design lessons that involve movement and interaction. Allow students to be more physically active, fostering engagement and utilizing their extra energy productively.

🎁Frequent Brain Breaks
Incorporate short, energizing breaks between lessons to allow students to release pent-up energy. Consider incorporating quick physical activities or holiday-themed games.

🎁Celebrate Achievements
Acknowledge and celebrate students’ achievements and positive behaviors leading up to the break. This positive reinforcement can motivate students to maintain good behavior during this energetic period.

🎁Create a Countdown Calendar
Build excitement for the upcoming break by creating a countdown calendar. Each day, engage in a short activity related to the countdown, adding an element of anticipation and fun to the classroom. You can also set a behavior goal each day for the class to accomplish.

🎁Incorporate Cooperative Learning
Plan group activities that encourage cooperation and teamwork. Students can work together on holiday-themed projects. 

🎁Flexible Lesson Plans
Be flexible with lesson plans and be prepared to adjust based on the energy levels of the class. If students seem particularly energetic, consider incorporating more interactive elements.

🎁Mindful Moments
Give students time to be mindful by drawing, coloring, listening to stories, or by having intentional quiet/think time.

🎁Embrace the Energy
As the old saying goes, “if you can’t beat ‘em, join ‘em!” Play holiday music, engage in the activities with your students, and have fun.

Make this simple art project with your students for Valentine’s Day!❤️

Use a 12x12 piece of construction paper.

Using a sharpie, draw five lines going down and five lines going across. Make sure they don’t intersect.

Then draw a heart in the center.

Use warm colors to color the heart and cool colors to color the background.

Have students try to alternate the color pattern. I like using oil pastels for this project, but you can use crayons, markers, or colored pencils.

Formative assessment is so much more than just exit tickets.🫠

I have seen firsthand how formative assessment has increased student outcomes, increased student engagement, and improved teachers instructional practices in intervention, small group rotation for individualized instruction, and student agency.

A lot of people talk about using formative assessment, but I think if you looked really closely, you would see a different story. By and large, formative assessment has not been adopted to the level it needs to be to impact student outcomes. 

It seems formative assessment is sprinkled into the curriculum across classrooms, but teachers still feel the pressure (from some admin) for grades in the grade book and are moving on to cover the material - even if their  students aren’t ready. 

To implement formative assessment effectively, you must be intentional, purposeful, and reflective. 

When you’re intentional, formative assessment
👉🏻gives clear expectations for student performance
👉🏻 creates frequent opportunities for feedback
👉🏻improves student performance
👉🏻increases student engagement and agency
👉🏻supports effective differentiation and scaffolding
👉🏻provides the best data-based instruction

If you want to learn more about different and effective ways to implement formative assessment, then check out my new book! 

There are over 70 resources, plus planning and collaboration strategies to support your formative assessment journey.

Use self assessment tickets to intentionally engage students and make them a part of the learning process. 👏🏻

Use self assessment tickets when you’re teaching new skills. They can be used for any content area. ❤️

State the learning goal at the beginning of your lesson and ask students to rate their level of understanding before you start the lesson.

Teach your lesson and then at the end, restate your learning goal and ask students to self assess their understanding. 🥰

Students should complete an independent practice that matches the learning goal and then staple their ticket to their work.

I like to use these turn in bins with my students. 👍🏻 They can turn in their work based on their level of understanding.

To read more about these ideas and to get the link to the tickets, comment TICKET.
